name: Dragons and Titans
description: Dragons and Titans is a fast paced MOBA with classic RPG elements. Select from over 30 unique dragons and 30 legendary weapons. Upgrade dragons and forge weapons to unlock more power. Free your Titan in 5v5 PvP battles across 3 different map types or play in ‘Adventure Mode’, traveling across different regions and unlocking rewards.

reviews.review_text: This game was quite dissapointing, I did buy the titans pass because it is fun for awhile, but it lacks many things that are standard in moba's these days.   Advantages: - Dragons are awesome and well designed artistically  - It's fun - graphics are average - lots of gamemodes and updates  disavantages: - you can't pick your dragon with your team, which is just horrible for a MOBA, you can end up with 5 supports or none, you can also have the same dragon as somebody else, this is very bad designed and makes the game unbalanced.  - you can't pick your game mode, it is rotated by the server, and you find out what gamemode you are playing after you select your dragon, some are better then others in certain maps. This is again, very poor design for a MOBA and even a basic MOBA needs this.  - Developers reasoning for bad design choices is that there isn't enough players to allow for people selecting there maps, this is very counter inuitive, because I'm sure more people would play if you could select your dragon as a team and chose the map. Which brings me to my next point.  - Small player base that isn't growing.  - global chatroom has people of all languges speaking in it, it should be seperated by language as you cannot communicate properly - the community that there is have been quite immature at times and quite toxic, there is only a few exceptions.  - lack of depth in gameplay   I do not recomend this game, but since it's free, you should try to see if you have fun with it, It still can be very fun at times but I would suggest if you wanted to play a dragon in a MOBA, you should go and play Jakiro on dota 2. (EDIT: OR WINTER WYVERN)

Dragons and Titans. Let's talk.   I saw this game, saw dragons, and thought 'Well, why not try it out. It's free so let's see what it's about.' And thus learned this is what a MOBA is called. For what it is, if you have no experience with any MOBAs it really is good. It's a great 'Get your feet wet' kinda game. Hell, I spent over 850 hours playing it so it must be good right? Right?! Well, frankly, if there was a 'neutral' button, I'd put it. If I had made my review a year ago, it'd be an absolute thumbs up reccomendation. As of now, I can't. It pains me to say it because this game is boat loads of fun. Was, I should say...  First, let's discuss how you begin: You start off with the tutorial, and afterwards get a dragon egg pack. There are like, 30 dragons and the egg packs are random. You could get x3 of the same dragon, x3 support, x3 damage, or just x3 crap dragons you suck at. It's 100% random. You can get more egg packs for 5,000 gems which are the currency in game, but it takes a while. The first egg pack you get is free. I've heard stories of people starting out with x3 support dragons which suck for a new player. But again. Random.  So, if you start out with dragons that are support or dragons that just arn't your playstyle, etc...you're going to have a tough time starting out. Did I mention 5,000 gems takes a while to get?   Sure you can buy individual dragons, with REAL money, but....do you if you JUST are trying out a game?  RNG aside, you start out now. There are 4 acts for the main storyline for single player, single player for the 4 MOBA maps, co-op vs ai, and pvp. You can only play the first act as the others are locked until you pay 20$ for the Titan Pass. I never got it. Payed for a few dragons though when they had a sale though.   Alright, now for game play. You can choose a dragon and weapon combo. Some are better than others and are overused in PvP but that's besides the point. Each dragon/weapon has two abilities, some passive, others active depending on the weapon/dragon. Traditional MOBA however.   You also have Runes which in truth are the main game changer. You have rune pages that you can customise for your game style. Each rune can be upgraded, but...RNG TIME! You need x3 t1 runes OF THE SAME to upgrade to t2, and x3 OF THE SAME t2 runes to upgrade to t3. How do you get t1 runes? A random t1 rune pack for 250 gems! And there's a super difference between a player with a rune page full of 15 t3 damage increase runes to a player with no runes, even if they have a same combo.   Oh, and each pvp match gives you about 30-100 gems on average, with 100 being the cap. Co-op gives 20-40 and single player about 10-25. So, those 5,000 needed gems start looking harder and harder to achive. Sure the Titan Pass increases your gem income per match but....20$.  Dragons are similar with you needing x3 t1 of the same dragons for t2, etc. But with random dragon egg packs....  Weapons can be fordged to be better using reagents you find in game so that's easy to do. You get more weapons for 2,500 gems...but it's a RANDOM weapon pack that you MAY easily get more of the same weapon if you're unlucky and more than one weapon is 100% useless.  But through all this it's a super fun game! It's engaging, you WANT to upgrade your dragons...you WANT to succeed for fun! So why not the reccomendation thumbs up?  Well, let's discuss why I stopped playing. Remember when I said that Runes can make or break a game? I would have a full rune page of damage runes mix with T2/T3 runes and deal so little damage it's pathetic. Then randomly, mid match (Sometimes never) I suddenly deal massive damage. With a page full of Cooldown runes, I notice my cooldown's aren't getting reduced. Then suddenly, mid match my cooldowns half they were.   My rune pages weren't always active. So, I send in a ticket like normal people and figure I'll stop playing for a while till it gets sorted out.   That was a year ago. No comments back.  Also, there were no updates to the game in over 6-7 months.   So, while it was (And is if the bugs don't kick in) a super fun game, until the bugs get worked out, I don't see much more redemption for the game.  Perhaps in due time I can update this and say it's back in business. But right now, it pains me to say... No.

Not being a big fan of MOBAs myself, I found this game to be extremely entertaining. I love the take on the genre, and I know others complain about the controls, but frankly, I found them to be a welcome change rather than click click click! Why is this game called Dragons and Titans? You're a dragon lord, who rides dragons into battle. Now, why this is cool is you get a dragon with it's own unique abilities, and your rider can use a helpful weapon, so rather than filling inventory with objects and potions you're using abilities you specify as you progress. Once you reach enemy base, you find YOUR Titan is trapped there, and once you break the cage, you free them.  Now for the negatives I noticed. If you are just trying to practice to get a feel for the game, you will want to go and do the prologue and the acts. That's fine and dandy, but the learning curve is harsh even on Easy (because yeah, when I'm new, I'm going to hit Easy, k?) So you will find yourself frustrated time and time again with going through the entire thing after losing 4 lives (4 total, you get 3 hearts, and once you die after that, you have to start over).  The biggest, most horrendously awful thing about this game: Sometimes, those acts bug out. Mobs will not come on que as they should to progress, leaving you looking around frustrated until you decide to quit. The good news here is that if you quit 'the match' (again, this is an act, not playing with others) you will be able to try it again and then the enemes spawn accordingly.   I don't know about you, but that seems almost game breaking to have to QUIT just to play the damn thing. I'm genuinely hoping this is addressed and repaired.  Aside from that, I do recommend this game, it's fun, the music is fantastic, and you feel like you're getting somewhere (when things aren't wonky). ===Edit=== Also, some people are complaining that this is a pay to win game. As of 3/15/2014 this game actually gives you freebies for doing tutorials and stuff. Free crystals to buy a pack of dragons and weapons. No, you can't specify which ones you get, but I'm not complaining x3

I wouldn't say this is pay to win, but it's definitely pay to get what you actually want. You can purchase what you 'need' with in game money but what you get is random; so if you wanted that shiny gold dragon on the list you either buy it with irl money or keep buying random ones with in-game money, which you won't want to do. Each random 'pack' of dragons (which is only three may I add) costs 5000 in-game money and you need more than one to get the highest teir dragon... Storyline missions and battles only give you around 20-60 each. Don't think you can complete tutorial objectives to speed this up as you start out either, how about a 50 reward for a task that requires you spend 150.  So you either want to pay or you're in for the hard slog for that shiny gold dragon you set your eyes on.  This game also doesn't have much to do when it comes to the matches in multiplayer and from what I've seen there is only one map per game-mode, making it rather boring after a while. The tutorial is lacking... the options are even more lacking... i.e. prety much non-existent, and I can see why it makes some people think facebook game... I also came to the realization that this game isn't technically free to play at all and that's a misleading claim to draw you in. The DLC for this is literally the game and theres only two parts of DLC so far, which may I just say you will not want. Each DLC gives you 10 relatively short missions and you have to complete each mission 15 times over with different requirements to unlock the best prize. That isn't replayability, it's just a SLOG. No prize is worth the aggrevation of dragging yourself through the same 10 scenarios 15 times over! So this game is not only mingy, but misleading, very short on content and is money-intensive.  I'm still playing it, but it's not getting a thumbs up from me.

Love this game! Awesome dragons, awesome weapons. My one and only complaint is that there is no way to buy the dragon or weapon or skin or avatar, etc you want. You either have to grind out 5000 gems and buy three random dragons, or do the daily reward. And even then, you're only getting dragons. There is no way to buy avatars or skins except by the Titan Pass. I don't like the Titan Pass because it takes the fun out of playing and grinding to get new stuff. I like having to earn gems to buy dragons, I just wish I could get more than just dragons and weapons and runes with the gems I earn. Even if the avatars and skins were like 10,000 gems or more then at least I could earn them myself.   A good idea for the people making money on this game:  Let people choose between grinding out a lot of gems to get the skins or avatars or buy them for real money.  OR  They can buy a specific skin or avatar with real money AND hold events every now and again to win a free or reduced price avatar or skin.   There just needs to be some way that players can get one specific thing in game they want. The Titan Pass takes the fun out of the game because it unlocks everything and leaves nothing but the gameplay, which is totally fun don't get me wrong, but part of the fun is grinding to unlock things bit by bit. It gives players a sense of accomplishment to unlock things themselves.   I have read through a good portion of the reviews and like 90 somthing % of them that like this game, complain about the Titan Pass so I am not alone in this and you might want to change it so that your number of players increases. People will pay $5 for an in game dragon. They are unlikely to pay $20 for every dragon. Yes, there are exceptions because it is a good deal if you look at what you're getting for $20, but for the rest of us, we're looking at the fact that you're taking away the fun of unlocking things.   Forgive the repetitiveness and lengthiness of this review and I really hope those in charge of how this game works will take my ideas into consideration.

A good concept ruined by poor execution.   All dragons, while unique in appearance are all very similiar. Each dragon only has two attacks, and almost all of them have a standard breath attack. So really dragons only have one attack that is different from another dragon. The way they tried to fix this, was with weapons. Equipping a weapon will give your dragon two more attacks depending on the weapon you equipped. The problem is, this doesn't make things more unique, it makes them more stale.   Say you and another dragon have the same weapon equipped. Well now you and that dragon only have one unique move between each other, and he's a completely different dragon. This is made even worse by the fact that there is no item shop in game. Dragons scale with levels, thats it. So while you might do good damage to an enemy DPS, theres nothing you can do to help you damage against a Tank, or if you need more HP to survive, theres no way to get it.  Speaking of 'no way to get it', thats what I have to tell you bout a dragon you might want to buy. You see, you don't just buy the one you want, oh no, you have to get lucky and play whats basically a slot machine and hope you get lucky. Oh you got the one you want you say? Well guess what, dragons actually have different levels outside of the game that make them stronger. So while you may have gotten that awesome Gemtalon I, he's nowhere near as strong or awesome as Gemtalon III.  Its a watered down moba, aiming to cash in on the popularity of dragons by locking them all behind a slot machine and hoping you spend a bunch of money to get one, before you realize the game isn't deep enough to warrant spending money.

this game would be awesome IF it wasn't for it needing soo many tweaks and fixes.   First of all is the targeting. you virtually have no control over it. sure you can hit the space bar to select the closest one to you, but too many times a bird would fly by and the dragon would act like the dogs from teh movie 'Up' when they saw a squirle and immediately auto target the bird. This is the game breaker for me. Too many times have i had a definate kill then all of a sudden a bird would fly by and my targeting would jsut switch and let teh enemy dragon get away.  Second, there are alot of balacing/Tech issues with the game. The Server lags tremendously. too many times do you hit a skill button and it does nothing, in match making it puts you in with other players that are way higher developed than you. For Example, when the more you play a particular weapon or dragon, the higher rank you get with it. it goes through the typic progression of no rank -> bronze -> silver -> gold -> diamond. when you rank your dragon up it moves faster and gets more health and the weapons get shorter cool downs on the skills it gives you. this is a huge advantage in games as either they can jsut out run you and get away or chase you down with you having no hope of escaping.  Thrid, is how oyu upgrade your dragons. they go from I - IV and they get bonuses each time they upgrade. you upgrade by getting 3 of a particular rank. you get dragons either by random chance by using crystals or you can buy the rank 1 for 2.99. if you have a dragon you really like and want to get it to rank IV you either have to get really luckky with the random eggs OR you can by it for 81$ US. Also as you lvl up you can start using Runes and to get runes you have to buy them with either crystals or using real money and even if you use real money the runes you get are totally random. this is basically a pay to win game and if I am going to use real money i want a definate choice on what I spend my money on, not a random chance.  Lastly is the game type selection. Instead of letting you choose the game type you want to play, the map is voted on and then for the next 30 min you HAVE to play that map.   This game is a huge let down because it has to the potential to be a great game, not only on the PC but console platforms too. The game play is fun, but incredibly fustrating with all the issues it has that I mentioned above. If they made the tweaks/Fixes to the issues i stated above I would definately recommend this game, but as it stands now I can NOT in good conscience recommend this game.

Great concept but terrible execution. Game is unbalanced as hell, and bug ridden. Every update introduce new unbalanced items and new bugs. Old bugs drag on for years and the devs pay little attention to the quality. The game started on a good concept but was ruined by the developers due to ignorance and incompetence.  There were 3 maps in the game, 2 of which were rubbish and nobody used to play maps other than the chaos/moba map. Instead of improving the other maps, they would force players to play random maps so the un-performing maps would be played. In addition, the 3 maps play differently, and the dragon/weapon selection would perform very differently depending on the map. This means no matter how much effort you put into this game, the outcome of a match is randomized, depending on which map it puts you into. This gives you an idea of the kind of people they are.  The dragon and weapon selection is made before entering a game, and before you see any of your teammates or their selections. This means the player cannot choose combos that compliment the teammates. For a moba game this is horrible as players can never find a balanced team. Getting into a game with all support units against all attackers means a waste of 5-20 minutes of time.  The game had a skill shot pvp system where players had to aim their shots. To dumb it down in a failed attempt to attract players, it was chcanged to auto-aim. So instead of maneuvering and finding an opening to shoot the opponent, players now hold down the mouse button and sit idle until someone dies or escapes. The weapons/dragons that are harder to hit but hits harder, are now auto-aimed just like the easier to hit pee shooters. They were left un-balanced after auto aim was implemented 1-2 years ago. Very little attention was paid to balance the gameplay, as a matter of fact, that there are only about a quarter of the dragons/weapons that provide competitive performance. The rest create useless combos that cause teammates to hate you.  The game is plagued with hackers and lag bugs. Hackers would speed hack to win. They are reported by various over a year and no action would be taken. As a matter of fact, we would write support/report emails and would not hear answers for months, or ever in most cases. The lag bugs cause problem in gameplay where players take damage from the position they were in 1-2 seconds ago. Thus from your own computer, you'd think you are out of fire range but would still be taking damage. Furthermore, players are harmed by all kinds of invisble fireball, dragon breath that the server decided not to display.  It is not bad to try out the game to taste the concept of a lighter version of moba. But the game is far from good and the devs are less than competent to bring it up to standard.

Ok whre to start. This Game is quite different from the usual Dotalike games. Its faster and round are shorter with usally more kills.  The movement system is one of the biggest differences. There is no klick to move to location. Instead the dragon moves forward by either pressing shift or right mouse button. And it is always facing the mouse coursor. Space is used to move the dragon backwarts. There is no sideways movement.  Most skills are skillshot fiering in a specific pattern from your dragon. For example dragon btreah usally fires out of the fron (duh)   It less complex than other titles because it doesnt have items to buy in a match as you collect gold. Instead your skills will be determined by dragon and weapon choice for a total of 4 skills (two from each) and 2 additional spells like it it done in lol.   There is a huge selection of Dragons (about 30) and weapons (about the same amount) all of which play somewhat differently. You get 3 random dragons and weapons permanently as part of the tutorial. Other than that you have the usual rotation of free dragons and weapons.  The forced tutorial is one of the worst parts of the games. You have to go through serveral singleplayer mission + one match against the AI (a quite short one, just explaining the dota like mechanics) if you want to have full access to the multiplayer part. This should take about 45 minutes of gameplay and could be a letdown for some people.  The game is somewhat pay to win. You can pay for dragons and weapons(randoms or specific ones) and only radom weapons ad dragons can be bought in ingame currency. Dragons can be upgraded by using 3 Tier1 or tier 2 dragons of the same type. They get some slight bonuses for it. Like 8% less mana cost and 4% more speed. Something about that line. It is achiveable by just playing but it will take quite a long time and you have to be lucky to get the right random dragons. Buying a tier 3 dragon costs about. 45€  There is a forging system which make weapons a bit stronger (something like 5% more damage, less cooldown, less mana cost) which can be payed for to get it as lot quicker.  And there is a rune system. which you can buy runes for with real money. (only random) Of couse tier2 and tier3 runes are available for non paying players too but they take a long times to craft it seems. (about 3 days for one tier 3 rune and one day for a tier 2 rune). Sadly i cannot asses how strong tier 3 runes are in comparison to tier 2 and 1. Here could be the part where the real pay to win could lie.  In total i would reccoment the game though. Its free and has dragons and it seems quite balanced and knowing the game is more important than bought 20% performance. You have to endure the tutorial though. Which isnt actually that bad.

Dragons and Titans used to be an awesome game. After several buffs and nerfs, the game wasn't any longer fun to play.    Things that I used to like about D&T that changed:   The possibilty to invite up to 5 friends to form a team.  Having to use all different dragons in a match.  The old controls system without auto-aim.  Anything before the Titan Pass.   D&T couldn't afford itself after the yearly Titan Pass, for it didn't create any beneficial profit.   What D&T should of change is:   Starting with the Titan Pass (Same price for a month is more than enough).  Remove all Runes (stones collected within the matches), since this allows players to easily use hacks and sometimes stay low profile, and as well helps to keep the abilities of the dragons balanced.  Remove the use of repeated dragons in a match.  Weekly updates, including at least 1 weapon or 1 dragon.  At least 3 Moderators per chat (since not all are always able to be online).  Weekly developer or admin visits so players notice the interest of the D&T team towards them. And last but not least, team XP in matches, instead of individual (This will give players a more pleasent and friendly match, since it will encourage all to assist for a common cause).  Some new ideas:  Replacing the collection of stones for Gold pieces to buy some upgrade for their weapons/dragons with a prior limit set, within the match. The upgrades could either have just a few levels but several type that does not mess the balance in match, such as ''Returning to hoard ability cooldown'', ''Short protective shield for teammates'', ''Dashing a small distance'', and stuff like that.  Anyways, there are many things that can be changed to make the game not just as good as it used to be, but greater. Lets not forget the improvements keep players interested, but every change must to be properly debated between D&T team, in order to avoid colliding every feature or element in the game.  At the end, there is far too much that can be improved in Dragons and Titans, but the income must to be well thought, that way the D&T team will always feel excited to work with such awesome game. The concept that this game handled is very insteresting and satifying, specially to those who love dragons. But if anyone wants the players to return to this game, a lot has to be done and responsabilities to be assumed.   Thanks D&T for so many fun moments and to allow me to meet some of the coolest and easy going people to play with.
